title: Restaurant gets one star reviews before even opening as it offered foie gras
text:
Maximillian Bennett, 28, has taken foie gras off his restaurant menu after receiving backlash (Picture: Barnetts at the Old Bank House/Getty Images/iStockphoto)

A young chef hoping for success with his new restaurant was marred by one star reviews before it even opened after putting foie gras on the menu.

Maximillian Bennett, 28, hopes for a Michelin Star one day, but was forced to change his new menu when activists targeted his new restaurant Barnetts at the Old Bank House in Somerset.

Foie gras has been condemned by many animal rights groups due to the fact that it is often made by force-feeding ducks or geese.

Activists left a string of one-star reviews and negative comments, spurring Mr Bennett to take the controversial dish off the menu.

Mr Bennett, who left his home in Leicester to learn his craft in London aged just 16, said: ‘We did not want to argue, nor did we want to start a debate – civil or otherwise.

‘However, given that Facebook has a commenting section, it spiralled rather quickly, which we weren’t expecting.

‘We were merely asking for a yes or a no, and it was finalised as a firm no, so respecting this, we have removed the dish.

Maximillian says the comments on the restaurant’s Facebook page ‘spiralled’ out of control (Picture: Barnetts at the Old Bank House)

Foie gras has been slammed by numerous animal rights groups because it is often made by force-feeding ducks or geese (Picture: Getty Images/iStockphoto)

‘We have taken into account that we have offended some of you, so for that, we apologise.

‘On the other hand, we are saddened by the fact that not all opinions offered were delivered with dignity and consideration.

‘It is never acceptable to make threats, nor are the recommendations as we have not even opened yet.

‘The comments and private messages were extreme to say the least, considering that in our poll we shared no opinion about the matter.

‘We were trying to connect with the community and some felt the need to punish us for our earnestness.’

He added: ‘We understand that foie gras is a delicate matter and that, as an issue, it provokes a myriad range of opinions.

‘We value and believe strongly in everyone’s right to an opinion which is why we set out to give the public their say in what to do.

The young chef left his home in Leicester to learn his craft in London aged just 16 (Picture: Barnetts at the Old Bank House)

Barnetts at the Old Bank House will open on November 1 in Castle Cary, Somerset (Picture: Barnetts at the Old Bank House)

‘Ultimately we have listened to the public’s resounding verdict and have decided to not put the fois gras on the menu.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘We hope changing the dish means we can focus on the opening of our new business.

‘We understand the strong feelings on both sides but would like to ask you to now to respect our decision and allow us to persevere in trying to make a success of our small business.

‘We hope to see some friendly faces in our restaurant. We welcome you all with open arms.’

The new restaurant is set to open on November 1 in Castle Cary, Somerset.

Despite the negative start, Mr Bennett says he aims to have ‘two AA Rosettes minimum’ in five years time and possibly a Michelin star in the future.

The budding restaurateur has worked in a number of one and two Michelin starred establishments and has been employed as a private chef for several professional footballers.

He said: ‘In five years’ time, I would like two AA Rosettes minimum and would like to be known as the best eatery in the area.

‘I think that’s realistic, I think we can do it and I’d like it to happen.

‘A Michelin star would be nice, but baby steps. We’ll tackle the rosettes first and then if we can we’ll go as high as we can.’

description: Maximillian Bennett's restaurant in Castle Cary, Somerset was marred by one star reviews before it opened after foie gras was on the menu.
